image.altText: Sharon Ah Chee and Tim Agius sit on a a park bench while a small white and brown dog with a black harness sits on Tim's lap

props.synopsis: Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands community members have been left disappointed by a last-minute decision to halt a hearing that was set to probe governance issues in the region.

title.children: APY Lands governance hearing delayed indefinitely

image.altText: Photo of Gus

props.synopsis: A renewed police search for missing four-year-old Gus is expected to enter its second day, with no indication of any clues revealed so far.

title.children: Mine search for Gus expected to resume as locals speak of shock and upset

image.altText: Gloved hands use tweezers to examine pink coloured sand in a zip-lock bag.

props.synopsis: SA's Minister for Education, Blair Boyer, is calling on retailers to help pay the climbing clean-up bill for removing coloured sand products linked to the asbestos scare.

title.children: Asbestos scare school bill tipped to exceed $1.5m in SA

image.altText: A close up historic shot of a man wearing aviator sunglasses.

props.synopsis: The ABC understands convicted child murderer Bevan Spencer von Einem has been taken to the Yatala infirmary in Adelaide where he only has a short time to live.

title.children: Notorious child killer on brink of death in jail

image.altText: A CFS firefighter in firefighting helmet and clothing.

props.synopsis: Tributes flow for a firefighter who was killed while attending a scrub fire on the Eyre Peninsula over the weekend.

title.children: Family of firefighter killed battling SA blaze pays tribute to 'great bloke'

image.altText: Two people in hi-vis stand around a large drilling machine which is pushing into the ground near farmland.

props.synopsis: A publicly listed resources exploration company says it will conduct further testing in early 2026 after initial drill samples show promising results.

title.children: Rare earth element exploration in SA Mallee region 'encouraging'

image.altText: An entertainment strip on a city street with images of provocatively dressed women on displays.

props.synopsis: A local councillor who tried to get reimbursed for a drink he bought at "the best strip club in Australia" during a work trip describes the incident as a "genuine mistake".

title.children: Councillor drank beer 'quickly' after realising he was in strip club

image.altText: Two people stand in a smoke-filled paddock with their arms around each other.

props.synopsis: Ten years after the Pinery bushfire tore through an area roughly the size of Greater Adelaide, those who were there reflect on how it changed their lives.

title.children: Community now better prepared 10 years on from deadly Pinery bushfire

image.altText: A young man in a check shirt in front of a mural.

props.synopsis: Youth homelessness support services say the pandemic and an associated surge in real estate prices have made it even harder to secure accommodation.

title.children: Rental market making it harder to help young people 'out of crisis homelessness'

image.altText: A man on a green tractor clearing downed trees.

props.synopsis: Port Pirie residents and businesses are picking up the pieces after record-breaking thunderstorms hit town over the weekend.

title.children: Clean-up underway following destructive thunderstorms in Port Pirie

image.altText: Golden wheat in the sunshine.

props.synopsis: ElectraNet are shifting their focus east, after farmers voiced concerns about renewable energy line Northern Transmission Project running through prime cropping country.

title.children: ElectraNet to change power corridor plan after farmers voice concerns

image.altText: Arabana ranger Zaaheer McKenzie at the site of a spring.

props.synopsis: Environmentalists are calling for mining giant BHP to end its water extraction from the Great Artesian Basin when a major desalination plant is built in South Australia's north.

title.children: Calls for BHP to end water extraction before culturally significant springs are lost

image.altText: A wide shot of Mount Gambier's Blue Lake.

props.synopsis: Most lakes are kind of blue, but this lake in South Australia stands out for its super-bright colour that attracts tourists from around the country. But just why it is so blue and why it changes colour during the year are not well known.

title.children: Why is Mount Gambier's Blue Lake so blue?

image.altText: Photo of Gus

props.synopsis: In their effort to find missing four-year-old Gus, police have vowed "explore every avenue" — which now includes several mine shafts around the property where he disappeared.

title.children: New phase in search for 4yo Gus with police to include six mine shafts

image.altText: A composite of Xi Jinping and Sanae Takaichi

props.synopsis: The incident comes amid an ongoing diplomatic spat between Tokyo and Beijing.

title.children: Japan scrambles jets after suspected Chinese drone spotted near Taiwan

image.altText: An illustration of four hands grabbing into a paper written 'Work and Holiday Visa'.

props.synopsis: Thousands of young Indonesians want the chance to come to Australia to work, but first they have to win a visa application "war" that puts them in the sights of scammers and dodgy operators promising them what they want — for a price.

title.children: 'The names have been selected': Crooked operators rig working visas

image.altText: Generic images of flames, equipment and RFS volunteers and staff conducting a hazard reduction burn at Tura Beach, NSW

props.synopsis: Eastern Australia is facing a barrage of extreme weather conditions this week, and for many areas the most intense conditions will arrive on Wednesday.

title.children: Extreme heat, winds and catastrophic fire danger for Australia's east

image.altText: A young, dark-haired boy in a bushy area.

props.synopsis: The grieving parents of a four-year-old boy who drowned in a suburban lagoon are suing Melbourne Water and a council over the tragedy.

title.children: Drowned boy was able to slip through 'ineffective' fence, lawsuit claims

image.altText: A white flower with big red spots on the petals is found nestled in the earth.

props.synopsis: A team of researchers have described the "magical" experience of finding a rare species of flower in bloom deep in the Sumatran rainforest after a 23-hour trek.

title.children: After a 13-year search, researchers discover a 'magical' rare flower bloom

image.altText: An armed guard standing outside the glass entrance to the Louvre.

props.synopsis: Four other people were already arrested and placed under formal investigation on October 29 and November 1.

title.children: Four more arrested in connection with Louvre jewel heist

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and wearing a red blazer.

props.synopsis: After it campaigned against a Coalition pledge to cut 41,000 public servants, Labor is ramping up its own efficiency drive in a move expected to cost jobs.

title.children: Labor puts squeeze on public service, sparking warnings of job losses

image.altText: NSW Police attend a fatal stabbing at Rouse Hill

props.synopsis: A boy is arrested and charged with murder after Riot Squad police raid a home in Rouse Hill.

title.children: Second 15yo charged with murder after fatal Sydney stabbing

image.altText: The ute-sized white popemobile is displayed inside a large glass box outdoors

props.synopsis: A former "Popemobile" used by Pope Francis during his 2014 tour of the Holy Land has been transformed into a mobile health clinic for Gaza's children, but Israeli authorities are yet to give permission for it to enter the war-ravaged strip.

title.children: Pope Francis's Popemobile transformed into mobile clinic for Gaza children

image.altText: Buildings in ruins after being hit by a cyclone

props.synopsis: A luxury wilderness resort only accessible by sea and air has been significantly damaged in a direct hit from Severe Tropical Cyclone Fina, which made landfall in an extremely remote part of WA.

title.children: Remote luxury resort in WA suffers severe damage after Cyclone Fina’s direct hit

image.altText: Bees sit covering a beehive frame

props.synopsis: The cost of treating varroa mite in the beekeeping industry is flowing onto other food growers reliant on pollination.

title.children: Beekeepers struggle amid fears varroa mite infestations are worsening in NSW

image.altText: A young Black man and a young white man with an arm slung over the shoulder, smiling

props.synopsis: In a world where celebrities are accessible on social media in a way they never were before, has fame lost its shine? A new film explores the parasitic relationship between stars and their fans.

title.children: 'Being famous isn't cool anymore': Lurker explores fandom and obsession

image.altText: A black-and-white photograph of Andy Warhol moving a polaroid camera away from his face. The polaroid is his portrait.

props.synopsis: On November 26, 1948, the first Polaroid camera was released commercially, changing photography forever.

title.children: How a daughter's 'puzzle' inspired one of the world's most popular cameras

image.altText: Two mean wearing white jumpsuits peer at a footpath using a torch in front of a white car.

props.synopsis: Forensics has provided the biggest breakthrough in criminal justice in the last century. It's also become the perfect subject matter for TV crime shows. But do you know forensic facts from fiction? Take our quiz to find out.

title.children: Fingerprints, fibres and DNA: Do you know forensic facts from fiction?

image.altText: US Senator Mark Kelly speaking to the media in a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: It comes after the six US politicians appeared in a social media video which Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth described as "seditious".

title.children: FBI set to interview Democrats who urged US military to ignore illegal orders

image.altText: A woman taking a selfie with a man and three young children, whose faces have been blurred.

props.synopsis: The family's alternative lifestyle came under scrutiny after the British-Australian couple and their three children were hospitalised last year with mushroom poisoning.

title.children: Children removed from Australian-British couple living off-grid in Italian forest

image.altText: Razor wire at the top of a fence.

props.synopsis: The ABC has heard of a five-year-old's distress at being unable to speak with her father in a Tasmanian prison. Workers say that lockdowns due to staff shortages are to blame.

title.children: Contact visits reduced at Tasmania's prisons due to staff shortages

image.altText: Sharon Ah Chee and Tim Agius sit on a a park bench while a small white and brown dog with a black harness sits on Tim's lap

props.synopsis: Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands community members have been left disappointed by a last-minute decision to halt a hearing that was set to probe governance issues in the region.

title.children: APY Lands governance hearing delayed indefinitely

image.altText: Members of the Indian women's football team are gathered together, celebrating

props.synopsis: Ranked 63rd in the world, India will need to finish ahead of Japan, Vietnam and Chinese Taipei to progress through next year's Women's Asian Cup and have a chance at their first-ever World Cup qualification.

title.children: India a 'realistic' chance to qualify for FIFA Women's World Cup: Coach

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce and Pauline Hanson chat around a table.

props.synopsis: At the end of this week, Barnaby Joyce will either confirm his exit from politics or join One Nation — at least, that is the binary choice the maverick former deputy prime minister has set for himself.

title.children: Joyce's looming defection could spell trouble for the Nationals

image.altText: A young woman standing in front of a red telephone booth in London

props.synopsis: Australians heading to London could soon pay a new "tourist tax" on accommodation as the British government moves to give cities across England the power to impose levies.

title.children: What the UK's proposed 'tourist taxes' mean for Australians
